headline.main: A Revenge Not So Sweet; Brooklyn Widow Wins Lawsuit Against Tobacco Company

docs.abstract: Gladys Frankson, widow of late Harry W Frankson, was paid $175,000 in compensation by Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation for death of her husband from lung cancer; New York State Supreme Court in Brooklyn (NYC) will decide now if she deserves millions of dollars in punitive damages in benchmark case including suits by individuals against tobacco companies; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Harry W. Frankson was a big, strong guy. It seems possible, his widow said the other day, that he never really believed cigarettes would kill him. Until the doctor told him it was too late. Lung cancer.

docs.abstract: New York State Governor George E Pataki administration adopts regulations to require cigarettes sold in state to be so-called fire-safe and extinguish themselves if no one is smoking them (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Pataki administration said on Wednesday that it had adopted regulations to require that cigarettes sold in New York State be manufactured with paper that can extinguish itself. The so-called fire-safe cigarettes stop burning if no one is puffing on them. Supporters of the new rules, which go into effect on June 28, say the cigarettes will prevent many of the fires now caused by smokers who leave cigarettes unattended, typically when they fall asleep and bedding or upholstery catches fire.
